data.title: Things to do in metro Detroit this weekend
data.meta_description: Concerts, plays, and more things to do this week.
data.text:
On sale now

• The Fighters: Tales from the Cage-Urijah Faber, Lyoto Machida, Henry Cejudo discussion: Oct. 18, Music Hall, Detroit, BroadwayInDetroit.com, ticket prices vary.

• Jerry Seinfeld: Second performance added, 10 p.m. Oct. 28, Fox Theatre, Detroit, ticket prices vary.

On sale 10 a.m. Aug. 18

• The Temptations and The Four Tops: Oct. 5, Fox Theatre, Detroit, ticket prices vary.

• Grace Potter: Nov. 2, Saint Andrew’s Hall, Detroit, ticket prices vary.

• Mrs. Doubtfire: Nov. 14-26, Fisher Theatre, Detroit, BroadwayInDetroit.com, ticket prices vary.

On sale 10 a.m. Aug. 24

• The Dramatics featuring L.J. Reynolds: Feb. 18, Sound Board at MotorCity Casino, Detroit, ticket prices vary.

On sale 10 a.m. Aug. 25

• Al Green, Angela Windbush: Nov. 24, Fox Theatre, Detroit, ticket prices vary.

Rescheduled

• Lil Uzi: Rescheduled to Dec. 3, (previously scheduled for Oct. 25), and venue changed to Little Caesars Arena, Detroit, ticket prices vary.

• Madonna: Rescheduled to Jan. 15, (previously scheduled for Aug. 8), Little Caesars Arena, Detroit, ticket prices vary.

Note: Events are subject to change; check with venues for updates. Tickets on sale at 313Presents.com, LiveNation.com, Ticketmaster.com or the XFINITY Box Office at Little Caesars Arena.

Beats

• LL COOL J, The Roots, DJ Jazzy Jeff, Common, Ice-T, Bone Thugs-N-Harmony, DJ Z-Trip and MC Lyte: 8 p.m. Aug. 18, Little Caesars Arena, Detroit, 313presents.com, ticket prices vary.

• Peso Pluma: 8 p.m. Aug. 18, Michigan Lottery Amphitheatre, Sterling Heights, 313presents.com, ticket prices vary.

• Goo Goo Dolls with O.A.R.: 7 p.m. Aug. 19, Michigan Lottery Amphitheatre, ticket prices vary.

• Bleeding Through: 2 p.m. Aug. 19, The Crofoot Ballroom, 1 S. Saginaw Pontiac, thecrofoot.com/events, $35+.

• Boys of Fall (Acoustic): Aug. 19, The Loving Touch, thelovingtouchferndale.com, doors open 7 p.m., all ages, donations accepted to benefit BeInstrumental, music education charity.

• Forever 27 – Tribute to Hendrix, Joplin and Morrison: 6-10 p.m. Aug. 19, Wildwood Amphitheater, 2700 Joslyn Ct., Orion Twp., bring lawn chairs or blanket, no outside food or beverage, www.orion.events, www.facebook.com/www.orion.events, $25+.

• Van Halen Tribute – Ft. Panama: 8 p.m. Aug. 19, The Roxy, 401 Walnut St. Rochester, theroxyrochester.com, doors at 7 p.m. ages 21+, $35+ adv.

• Sunny Side Jazz Band: 7:30 p.m. and 9:30 p.m. Aug. 17-19, Cliff Bell’s jazz club, 2030 Park Ave. Detroit, Cliffbells.com, 313-961-2543. $25+ each. Food and beverages to purchase. Seating at 5 p.m. for dinner. Seating begins at 6 p.m. for “Dinner & a Show”. The second show starts seating at 9 p.m.

• Manchester Orchestra and Jimmy Eat World: 7 p.m. Aug. 20, Michigan Lottery Amphitheatre, 313presents.com, ticket prices vary.

• The Beach Boys: 7:30 p.m., Aug. 20, Meadow Brook Amphitheatre on the campus of Oakland University, 313presents.com, ticket prices vary.

• Theatre Bizarre Orchestra: 6:30 p.m. Aug. 22, Ferndale Area District Library, 222 E. Nine Mile, Ferndale, www.ferndalepubliclibrary.org.

• The All-American Rejects, New Found Glory, The Starting Line and The Get Up Kids: 7 p.m. Aug. 22, Michigan Lottery Amphitheatre, 313presents.com, ticket prices vary.

• Barry Manilow: 7 p.m., Aug. 22, Little Caesars Arena, Detroit, 313presents.com, ticket prices vary.

Festivals

• GreekFest: Aug. 17-20, Assumption Greek Church, 21800 Marter Road, St. Clair Shores, 586-779-6111, www.assumptionfestival.com.

• Woodward Dream Cruise: Aug. 18-19, activities include car shows, car parades and entertainment, in communities along Woodward Avenue, woodwarddreamcruise.com. Mitch Ryder and The Detroit Wheels to be on stage at 9:10 p.m. Aug. 18, downtown Pontiac at Saginaw and Water Street. Ronnie McNeir and Company to perform at 8:15 p.m. Aug. 19, and The Voices of Classic Soul (former lead singers of Temptations, Platters, Drifters, and 4 Tops), will perform at 9:15 p.m. Aug. 19, free concerts, free parking.

• Mad Music and Arts Festival: 1-8 p.m. Aug. 19, Hess Hathaway, 825 S. Williams Lake Road, Waterford Twp., featuring live music, children’s art stations, food trucks, www.facebook.com/WaterfordParksandRec, www.waterfordmi.gov/1329/Parks-Recreation, rain or shine, free admission, charity event for suicide prevention and mental health.

• Grosse Pointe Art Fair: 11 a.m.-6 p.m. Aug. 19-20, Ford House Visitor Center, 1100 Lake Shore Road, Grosse Pointe Shores, Adults $7, children 6-12 years old $5, free for 5 and younger. Admission to tour the Ford Mansion is an additional fee. Parking is free. Advance tickets at www.GrossePointeArtFair.com.

• The Michigan Renaissance Festival: 10 a.m.-7 p.m. Saturdays and Sundays, Aug. 19-Oct. 1, and Labor Day, Sept. 4 and Festival Friday, Sept. 29, at 12600 Dixie Hwy., Holly, michrenfest.com. interactive outdoor event styled as a 16th Century European village with entertainment of the time period, vendors and food. Themed weekends include Pirates & Pups-Aug. 19-20 and Highland Fling-Aug. 26-27, parking pass required, ticket prices vary.

• Armada Fair: Through Aug. 20, Armada Fairgrounds, 74280 Fair Street, Armada. Country singer Jameson Rodgers to perform at 8:30 p.m. Aug. 14, events include rodeo events, tractor pulls, 4H events, carnivals, and fair food, armadafair.org.

• 2nd Annual Family Appreciation Day is 11:30 a.m. – 4 p.m. Aug. 20, UWM Sports Complex, 867 South Boulevard East, Pontiac, family activities, lunch, presented by E-Community Outreach Services, register at www.eventbrite.com/e/family-appreciation-day-tickets-636598211387?aff=ebdssbdestsearch, free event.

• Annual Summer Block Party: 5:30-9 p.m. Aug. 23, downtown Franklin, featuring entertainment by the Sean Blackman Trio and the Bloomfield Hills High School Drumline, food trucks, craft cocktails by Tangerine Wine, and ice cream truck. Children’s activities include Arts and Scraps projects, Touch-a-Truck, caricature artist. Proceeds benefit the Main Street Franklin Fund. Event includes free popcorn and water. RSVP to mainstreetfranklinmi.com. Franklin-based businesses or organizations interested in participating, can email mainstreetfranklinmichigan@gmail.com.

• Summer Bash: 5-8 p.m. Aug. 24, at Beaudette Park, 786 Orchard Lake Road, Pontiac, presented by Pontiac Youth Recreation Community Policing Team, www.pontiac.mi.us.

• Annual Dragon on the Lake Festival: Aug. 24-27, downtown Lake Orion, featuring dragon boat races on Lake Orion, art fair, a chalk art contest, the Little Dragon Den, the Dragon Pub, a Tiki Tent, live music, https://dragononthelake.com, Orion Art Center fundraiser.

• Plymouth Nativity’s Taste of Greece Festival: Aug. 24-27, Nativity of the Virgin Mary Greek Orthodox Church, 39851 West Five Mile Road, Plymouth, www.michigangreekfestival.com.

• Clawson Fest: 2-8 p.m. Aug. 26, on Main Street, (between 14 Mile and Tacoma) Clawson, live music, food, artisans, Kid’s Zone, and Dave Santia, world-renowned performance speed painter, 6-6:30 p.m., clawsonfest.com.

Outdoor concerts

Participants are encouraged to bring lawn chairs or blankets to these outdoor concerts.

• Summer Concert Series: 7-8:30 p.m. Aug. 18, Stony Creek Metropark, Eastwood Beach, 4300 Main Park Drive, Shelby Twp., www.metroparks.com/concerts, valid Metroparks daily or annual vehicle pass is required. Dave Hamilton Band is Aug. 18.

• Sounds Like Summer Concert Series: The Mitten Strings-Classical Quartet is 6:30-7:30 p.m., Aug. 22, Veterans Park, 200 W. Livingston Road, downtown Highland, www.highlanddda.com/events-attractions.

• Free concerts at Wildwood: 7-8:30 p.m. Tuesdays, through Aug. 22, Wildwood Amphitheater, 2700 Joslyn Ct., Orion Twp., visit orion.events for free tickets, bring lawn chairs or blankets.

• Music in the Park: 7-9 p.m. Thursdays through Aug. 24, Dodge Park, 40620 Utica Road, Sterling Heights, sterling-heights.net.

• Summer Sensation Concert Series: 6:30-8:30 p.m. select Thursdays, Thornetta Davis-Aug. 24, at Boulan Park, 3671 Crooks Road, Troy. Food truck starting at 5:30 p.m., troymi.gov, bring lawn chairs or blankets.

• Music in the Parks concert series: 6:30 p.m. select dates at Pontiac Parks, bring blankets or lawn chairs, pontiac.mi.us, concerts through the summer. Phat Greasy featuring Melanie Rutherford is Aug. 24 at Rotary Park, Wessen St at Walnut St (District 1); Persuasion w/sg Consuming Arts is Sept. 7 at Murphy Park, Martin Luther King Blvd at Osmun St (District7).

• Friday Night Live concert series: 7-9 p.m. Aug. 25, Center Street Park, downtown Milford, www.facebook.com/huronvalleycouncilforthearts.

• Friday Nights Downtown Music Series: 7-8:30 p.m. Fridays, through Aug. 25, Riverside Park Amphitheater, 3311 Squirrel Ct., Auburn and Squirrel, Auburn Hills, auburnhills.org/calendar.php.

• Food trucks and entertainment: 5-9 p.m. Fridays through Aug. 25, The Village of Rochester Hills, Festival Park, Rochester Hills, local entertainment, food trucks, mobile bar, bring lawn chairs or blankets, thevorh.com.

• LOLive! Concerts in the Park: 6:30-8 p.m. Wednesdays through Aug. 30 Children’s Park, downtown Lake Orion between Broadway and Anderson, downtownlakeorion.org.

• Live at The Pavilion: Live music, 6-10 p.m. Saturdays through the summer, Hotel Royal Oak Pavilion, 811 E. 11 Mile Road, Royal Oak, hotelroyaloak.com, free, bring lawn seating, free.

• Nine on Nine Concert Series: 4-5 p.m. Sundays through Sept. 3, Schiffer Park, at Nine Mile and Planavon Street, Ferndale, downtownferndale.com/events.

• Summer Concert Series: 6:30-9 p.m. Sundays through Sept. 3 at Lake St. Clair Metropark Thomas Welsh Activity Center, 31300 Metro Pkwy, Harrison Twp., www.metroparks.com/concerts, valid Metroparks daily or annual vehicle pass is required.

• Jazzy Nights: Wednesdays through Sept. 6, The Aretha Franklin Amphitheatre, 2600 Atwater St., Detroit, thearetha.com, ticket prices vary. Avery Sunshine-Aug. 23, Kelly Price-Aug. 30, Raheem Devaughn-Sept. 6

• Uptown Friday Night Concert Series is 7-9 p.m. Fridays through Sept. 8, (5 p.m. Aug. 18), Fountain Stage, Macomb Place, Mt. Clemens, facebook.com/DowntownMountClemens.

• Summer concert series: 7-9 p.m. Fridays and Saturdays through September, downtown Northville, www.downtownnorthville.com.

Theater

• “Aladdin Jr.”: 7 p.m. Aug. 18 and 2 p.m. Aug. 19, presented by StArt Youth Theatre at Flagstar Strand Theatre, 12 N. Saginaw St., Pontiac, www.flagstarstrand.com, $15+ adults, $10+ children.

• Shakespeare in Detroit-“The Tempest”: 7:30 p.m. Fri-Sun. Through Aug. 20, Campus Martius Park, 800 Woodward Ave., Detroit, shakespeareindetroit.com, free admission.

• Michigan Shakespeare Festival: Through Aug. 20, The Village Theatre at Cherry Hill Road, 50400 Cherry Hill Road, Canton, www.cantonvillagetheater.org.

• Canterbury Comic Cosplay Convention: Aug. 18-20, Canterbury Village, 2325 Joslyn Road, Orion Twp., featuring wrestling legend Ric Flair, TV actor Butch Patrick, celebrity meet and greets, published comic book artists, cosplay/comic vendors, roaming costumed characters, live entertainment, food and beverages. Ticket prices vary and must be purchased online in advance at www.CanterburyCosplay.com. Parking is $5 per vehicle.

Art

• Van Gogh Exhibition-Immersive Experience Detroit: Aug. 18-Oct. 1, Lighthouse ArtSpace Detroit, 311 E Grand River Ave., Detroit, lighthouseimmersive.com/disney/detroit, $24-$30+.

• Art Divisions of Farmington Hills and Farmington open nominations for Residence Award and the Distinguished Service to the Arts Award. The deadline to nominate groups, organizations, businesses, or individuals is Aug. 25.

• Free Cyanotype Activity – Workin’ Roots: 11 a.m.-1 p.m. Aug. 27, at 20103 Danbury, Detroit, https://cranbrookartmuseum.org/events/free-cyanotype-activity-workin-roots, free cyanotype constellation-making activity based on the artwork “Finding Freedom” by Sonya Clark, on view at Cranbrook Art Museum through Sept. 24.

• Artwork of Farmington Public School Students: Through Aug. 31, Farmington Hills City Hall atrium, 31555 W. Eleven Mile Road, Farmington Hills. Open 8:30 a.m.-4:30 p.m.,Monday to Friday, exhibit features student visual arts and photography winners based on the theme, “Show Your Voice,” www.FHgov.com.

• “Over the Moon” exhibit: Starkweather Arts Center, 219 N. Main St., Romeo, www.starkweatherarts.com, 586-752-5700, open 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Thursday through Saturday.

• “Free Your Mind: Art and Incarceration in Michigan”: Through Sept. 3, at Michigan and Museum of Contemporary Art Detroit (MOCAD), 4454 Woodward Ave., Detroit, mocadetroit.org/free-your-mind, presented with support from the Michigan Justice Fund at the Community Foundation for Southeast Michigan, cfsem.org/mjf.

• Gary Tyler “We are the Willing”: Exhibit through Sept. 6, Library Street Collective, 1274 Library St., Detroit, lscgallery.com.

• “Just Ducky” Outdoor Art Exhibition: Through September, on Waterford’s Riverwalk, along the Clinton River by Highland Road, west of Crescent Lake Road, Waterford Twp. 108 duck cutouts that have been decorated hanging in the trees along the Riverwalk, www.waterfordmi.gov.

• Amanda Koss-“Conversations With Myself”: Exhibit through Sept. 22, Color | Ink Studio, 20919 John R Road, Hazel Park, free admission, ColorInkStudio.com, gallery is open most weekdays by appointment, 248-398-6119.

• Sonya Clark exhibit ”We Are Each Other”: Through Sept. 24, Cranbrook Art Museum, 39221 Woodward Ave., Bloomfield Hills, 248-645-3323, cranbrookartmuseum.org, general admission ticket is $20.

• Laurie Tennent Art Gallery Exhibition: Through Sept. 28, Strand Art Gallery, located in the second floor of the theatre. Free admission, call 248-309-6445 and leave a message to schedule a tour or email boxoffice@flagstarstrand.com.

• James Barnor-Accra/London-A Retrospective, the work of Ghanaian photographer James Barnor: Through Oct. 15, Detroit Institute of Arts, Detroit, advanced reservations are required to visit the museum, 313-833-4005, dia.org/art/exhibitions.

• Inside|Out brings high-quality reproductions of the DIA’s collection to outdoor venues throughout metro Detroit: Through October, dia.org/events/insideout-2023.

• Thursdays at the Museum: 1 p.m. Thursdays. Detroit Institute of Arts, Detroit, self-guided visit of our collections for adults 55 and older. Groups of 25 or more in Wayne, Oakland, and Macomb counties can receive free bus transportation, www.dia.org/events/thursdays.

• Vitality and Continuity-Art in the Experiences of Anishinaabe, Inuit, and Pueblo Women: Through Jan. 6, Detroit Institute of Arts, Detroit, dia.org.

• The Hawk Makerspace: The Hawk – Farmington Hills Community Center, featuring craft space, specialized equipment including a laser cutter, 3D printer, and sewing lab. Makerspace users may purchase passes to use the equipment during Open Studio hours. Classes are also offered, fhgov.com/play,-explore-learn/the-hawk/amenities/makerspace.

• University of Michigan Museum of Art, 525 South State St, Ann Arbor, 734-764-0395, umma.umich.edu.

Auditions

• Auditions for “A Chorus Line”: 6-10 p.m. Aug. 17, Aug. 18 and Aug. 21, Nicely Theatre Group, at The Berman Center for the Performing Arts, 6600 West Maple Road, West Bloomfield Twp., ages 18+, non-equity actors only, nicelytheatregroup.org.

• Detroit Metropolitan Youth Symphony auditions: Aug. 19 at The Hawk in Farmington Hills, www.detroitmys.org, $30 application fee.

• Auditions for “A Little Princess” The Musical: Aug. 23-24, Dream Arts Company, show is Oct. 13-15. Youth and teens ages 7-18 and adults are eligible to audition, dacompany.org.

• Troy Community Chorus: Open to new members for fall season. Registration is 6:30-7:30 p.m. Sept. 5, Sept. 12, and Sept. 19, followed by full rehearsals from 7:30-9:30 p.m., in the choir room at Troy Athens High School, 4333 John R. Road, $45/individual or $80/couple, www.troycommunitychorus.com.

Beats, contd.

• Lil Baby, GloRilla, Gloss Up, Rylo Rodriguez: 7 p.m. Aug. 23, Little Caesars Arena, ticket prices vary.

• The Offspring, Sum 41 and Simple Plan: 7 p.m., Aug. 23, Pine Knob Music Theatre, Independence Twp., 313presents.com, ticket prices vary.

• The Swing Syndicate Big Band: 6 p.m. Aug. 23, Rochester Hills Public Library, open to RHPL library card holders. Registration is required at calendar.rhpl.org or call 248-656-2900.

• Jonas Brothers: 7 p.m. Aug. 24, Little Caesars Arena, 313presents.com, ticket prices vary.

• Motor City Blues featuring Laith Alsaadi, The Rusty Wright Band: 7-9:30 p.m. Aug. 24, Wildwood Amphitheater, 2700 Joslyn Ct., Orion Twp., bring lawn chairs or blanket, no outside food or beverage, www.orion.events, www.facebook.com/www.orion.events, $20+.

• Michigan Phil at the Movies: 6:30 p.m. Aug. 25, Ford Estate, 1100 Lake Shore Road Grosse Pointe Shores, Michigan Philharmonic performs music from films, www.fordhouse.org/events/michigan-philharmonic-at-ford-house, gen adm. tickets are 25+, 12 and younger tickets are $10+, grounds open at 5 p.m., concessions.

• Trapt: 7-11 p.m. Aug. 25, Diesel Concert Lounge, 33151 23 Mile Road, Chesterfield Township, 586-933-3503, www.dieselconcerts.com, $24.15+ adv.

• Toby Keith Tribute: 8 p.m. Aug. 26,The Roxy, 401 Walnut St. Rochester, theroxyrochester.com, doors at 7 p.m. ages 21+, $25+ adv.

• Nikell Johnson and Groove Session: 8 p.m. Aug. 26, Cornerstone Village Bar and Grille, 17315 Mack Ave., Detroit, 313-821-4998, $15 cover.

• Alvvays, Alex G: 6 p.m. Aug. 30, Royal Oak Music Theatre, 318 West 4th St., Royal Oak, www.royaloakmusictheatre.com, all ages, $35-69.50+.

• Don McLean: 8 p.m. Aug. 31, Flint Institute Of Music, Flint, doors at 7 p.m., https://thefim.org/event/don-mclean, ticket prices vary.

• Jonathan Bree with Ryder The Eagle: Aug. 31, The Magic Bag, 22920 Woodward Ave., Ferndale, all ages, doors at 8 p.m., www.themagicbag.com, $18+ adv.

• Cliff Erickson: 7-9:30 p.m. Fridays through mid-September, live music on the patio at The Statler French American Bistro, 313 Park Ave., Detroit, reservations are encouraged at https://statlerdetroit.com.

Comedy

• Mark Ridley’s Comedy Castle: Cam Rowe-Aug. 17-19; at 310 S. Troy St., Royal Oak, comedycastle.com, 248-542-9900, ages 18+, ticket prices vary.

• One Night Stans: Mike Armstrong-Aug. 17-19; at 4761 Highland Road, Waterford Twp., OneNightStans.Club, 248-249-1321, 18+, ticket prices vary.

• Bill Bushart: 10 p.m. Aug. 18, The Roxy, 401 Walnut St. Rochester, theroxyrochester.com, doors at 9:30 p.m. ages 21+, $25+ adv.

• Eddie B’s Teachers Only Comedy Tour 23′: 7 p.m. Aug. 26, Royal Oak Music Theatre, 318 West 4th St., Royal Oak, all ages, www.royaloakmusictheatre.com, $35-$55+.

Film

• The Oakland County Republican Party is partnering with Hope Against Trafficking, a nonprofit that raises funds to help rescue trafficking victims, to host a screening of “Sound of Freedom”, at 5:30 p.m. Aug. 21, at the Waterford MJR Cinema, 7501 Highland Road, Waterford Twp. Tickets can be purchased at https://hopeagainsttrafficking.org/event/sound-of-freedom-private-screening. Proceeds from the movie benefit Hope Against Trafficking.

• Flashback Cinema Series: Sundays and Wednesdays, August and September, variety of classic films showing at Emagine Theatres, www.emagine-entertainment.com/flashback-cinema.

• Emagine Theatres specialty screenings: Open caption, sensory-friendly and dementia-friendly screenings are offered at Emagine locations including Novi, Rochester Hills, Royal Oak, Hartland, Woodhaven, Emagine-Entertainment.com.

• Detroit Film Theatre at the Detroit Institute of Arts, 5200 Woodward Ave., Detroit, dia.org, ticket prices vary.

• Farmington Civic Theater: 33332 Grand River Ave., Farmington, theFCT.com, 248-474-1951, $8.50+ gen. adm., $5.75 matinee, free for members.

• The Maple Theater: 4135 W. Maple Road, Bloomfield Twp., themapletheater.com, 248-855-9091, $12+.

• Milford Independent Cinema: 945 E Summit St., Milford, milfordcinema.org/tickets, $5+.

• Redford Theatre: 17360 Lahser Road, Detroit, redfordtheatre.com, ticket prices vary.

Fundraisers

• Detroit Discovery Ball: 6:30- 11 p.m. Nov. 11, at The Fillmore, 2115 Woodward Ave., Detroit, proceeds benefit the American Cancer Society. Emcees are Christy McDonald, WDIV and Roop Raj, Fox 2 Detroit. The event includes live and silent auctions, dinner and late-night dancing. The attire is Detroit Chic Cocktail. An afterglow featuring live music by The Dan Rafferty Band. Individual tickets are $250, (includes valet parking) at www.detroitdiscoveryball.org.

Misc.

• “The Journey Within-An evening of Meditation and Wisdom”: Aug. 22, at The Detroit Symphony Orchestra Hall, 3711 Woodward Ave, Detroit. Presented by Gurudev Sri Sri Ravi Shankar, a global humanitarian, spiritual leader, and peace envoy, www.artofliving.org.

• Book signing: Paul Vachon, author of “Detroit: An Illustrated Timeline, 2nd Edition” is 7-8 p.m. Aug. 24, Royal Oak Public Library, 222 E Eleven Mile Rd, Royal Oak, 248-246-3700, www.ropl.org/1532/Library.

Museums

• Royal Oak Historical Society Museum: Open 1-4 p.m. Tuesday Thursday and Saturdays, 1411 W Webster Road, Royal Oak, 248-439-1501, $10+ suggested donation, royaloakhistoricalsociety.com.

• Smithsonian exhibition exploring the importance of work in American life: “The Way We Worked” is through Nov. 5, during library hours, at the Orion Township Public Library, 825 Joslyn Road, Lake Orion. The library will also be planning tie-in upcoming programming, orionlibrary.org, 248-693-3000.

• Greater West Bloomfield Historical Society: Open 1st/2nd/4th/5th Sundays of the month and 3rd Fridays, 1-4 pm, (holidays excluded) with exhibits including “Four Communities” exhibit at The Orchard Lake Museum, 3951 Orchard Lake Road, Orchard Lake. Admission is free, donations are welcome, www.gwbhs.org, 248-757-2451.

• Detroit Historical Museum: The Hustle-Shopkeepers & Stylists exhibit, an ongoing project honoring contemporary Black Detroit entrepreneurs, go.detroithistorical.org/DHMevents.

• The Rochester Hills Museum at Van Hoosen Farm at 1005 Van Hoosen Road, Rochester Hills, participates in the annual Blue Star Museums, offering free admission to the nation’s active-duty military personnel and their families, including National Guard and Reserve. The Blue Star Museums program through Labor Day, Sept. 4. A list of participating museums nationwide is at arts.gov/bluestarmuseums.

• “Trilobite Treasures-Arthropods of the Ancient Seas”: Through Sept. 10, Cranbrook Science Museum, 39221 Woodward Ave., Bloomfield Hills, 248-645-3200, science.cranbrook.edu, general museum admission plus $3.

• Michigan Science Center: 5020 John R. St., Detroit, mi-sci.org, 313-577-8400, museum gen. adm. is $18+. Traveling Science Program returns Aug. 25, outside of Mi-Sci’s main entrance from 10 a.m. – noon Aug. 25, featuring live science demonstrations and hands-on activities. Standard Mi-Sci films are available as a $6 add-on to general admission tickets, www.mi-sci.org. Mi-Sci is open 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Wednesday through Sunday and until 8 p.m. the first Friday of every month. The center participates in Museums for All, museums4all.org, patrons show their SNAP EBT card and picture ID and receive reduced admission.

• Motown Museum: Open for tours, 2648 W. Grand Blvd., Detroit, register at motownmuseum.org.

• Ford House: Historic estate of Edsel and Eleanor Ford, 1100 Lake Shore Road, Grosse Pointe Shores, fordhouse.org/events, 313-884-4222.

• Cranbrook Institute of Science, 39221 Woodward Ave., Bloomfield Hills, science.cranbrook.edu/visit/events/2022-10/sue-t-rex-experience-opens, general museum admission.

• Detroit Historical Museum: 5401 Woodward Ave. (NW corner of Kirby) in Midtown Detroit, detroithistorical.org. Permanent exhibits include the famous Streets of Old Detroit, the Allesee Gallery of Culture, Doorway to Freedom: Detroit and the Underground Railroad, Detroit: The “Arsenal of Democracy,” the Gallery of Innovation, Frontiers to Factories, America’s Motor City and The Glancy Trains, museum gen. adm. is $10.

• Meadow Brook Hall offers Guided House Tours and Self-Guided Tours, check available times and purchase tickets at meadowbrookhall.org/tours, ticket prices vary. Meadow Brook Hall, 350 Estate Drive, Rochester, on the campus of Oakland University.

• Dossin Great Lakes Museum, 100 Strand Drive, Belle Isle, Detroit, detroithistorical.org.

• Belle Isle Nature Center: 176 Lakeside Drive, Detroit. Recent renovations and new programs and exhibits including the Sewer Tunnel Walk, Detroit Zoological Society, belleislenaturecenter.detroitzoo.org.

• The Henry Ford Museum of American Innovation and Greenfield Village: 20900 Oakwood Blvd., Dearborn, Ford Rouge Factory Tours Monday-Saturday, purchase tickets online, prices vary, thehenryford.org.

• Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History, 315 E. Warren Ave., Detroit, 313-494-5800, 9 a.m.-4 p.m., reserve timed tickets at thewright.org, $25+ gen adm.

• Sloan Museum of Discovery: 1221 E. Kearsley St., Flint, www.sloanmuseum.org, 810-237-3450, admission prices vary.

• Michigan Activity Pass: Available for card holders of all Michigan public libraries, for free or discounted admission to more than 450 locations, including historic sites, cultural attractions and state parks, plymouthrockets.com/michiganactivitypass.
